10.title: Most favoured nation duties
10.content:
Most Favoured Nation dutiesWhat is the Most Favoured Nation principle?


Under the WTO agreements, countries cannot normally discriminate between their trading partners. Grant someone a special favour (such as a lower customs duty rate for one of their products) and you have to do the same for all other WTO members.
MFN duties are those that are applied globally without favour or privilege.

Why ‘most-favoured’?


This sounds like a contradiction. It suggests special treatment, but in the WTO it actually means non-discrimination — treating virtually everyone equally. Each member treats all the other members equally as “most-favoured” trading partners.
If a country improves the benefits that it gives to one trading partner, it has to give the same “best” treatment to all the other WTO members so that they all remain “most-favoured”.
There are exceptions …


countries can set up a free trade agreement that applies only to goods traded within the group
they can give developing countries special access to their markets GSP.
a country can raise barriers against products that are considered to be traded unfairly from specific countries.

But the agreements only permit these exceptions under strict conditions.
In general, MFN means that every time a country lowers a trade barrier or opens up a market, it has to do so for the same goods or services from all its trading partners — whether rich or poor, weak or strong.

MFN - universal and the lowest common denominator

The MFN is unique, inasmuch as there must be coverage of the entire tariff with one of two measure types (or both):


103 (Third country duty)
105 (Non preferential duty under end-use)

There are c. 24,500 commodity codes on the Tariff, of which c. 16,500 are declarable end-lines – every single one of these end-lines has an MFN duty against it
In a lot of cases, the MFN rate is 0%, but that 0% still needs to be actively set against the commodity.
The MFN is what will be charged unless the trader actively takes steps to take advantage of a more preferential rate, such as a tariff preference associated with a Free Trade Agreement or a quota.
It’s vital when we come to migrate data for the UK’s own MFN after the end of the Implementation Period that coverage of the commodity code base is complete (103s and 105s).


Concept – Unilateral liberalisationIn the run-up to the three abortive No Deal cliff-edges, the UK was prepared to launch our independent trade policy with a vastly different tariff compared to the MFN as part of the EU’s Common External Tariff (CET).
The UK would have imposed ”Unilateral liberalisation” on our country’s MFN duties. The reason for this was to reduce the immediate ‘toxic shock’ of leaving the EU with no period for businesses to get used to the new (absence of) relationship with Europe.
For example, any business in the UK that relied on 0% import duties of goods from the rest of Europe would find being thrust into the new reality of paying EU CET MFNs a price that could bankrupt them.
Due to the MFN principle (the great leveller), we had no way of applying preferential duties solely to the EU, from where we had been importing duty-free as a member state, therefore the concept of ‘unilateral liberalisation’ was essentially the only legal route forward that protected businesses against an immediate, potentially terminal, hike in duties.
This would have left duties on c. 900 lines out of the 16,500 MFNs.
What did we not liberalise?There were three pots of commodities whose MFN duties we would not have liberalised in a No Deal scenario:
Trade Remedies
Anti-dumping and anti-subsidy duties have been calculated to provide a protectionist measure for domestic industry in such a way that the MFN and the punitive duties combined are calibrated precisely to raise the price of the goods being brought in at an illegally low price back to a level playing field.
If the MFN were liberalised, then the protection is partially eroded and trading with the companies who have such duties becomes attractive again.
Sensitive lines
There are some commodities, most often in the agricultural space that were considered so sensitive to the adverse effects of liberalisation that their duties would have been retained to prevent injury to UK providers of such goods.
Negotiating capital
In order to retain some leverage for future trade agreements, there were 
some commodities that were left with a non-liberalised MFN, such that we 
could offer them as carrots in negotiations.
MFN duties after the Implementation PeriodAs of March 2020, it is not yet possible to predict precisely what will happen with the MFN duties after the end of the Transition Period, though we will know very soon.
Unilateral Liberalisation was intended solely to be a temporary measure in a No Deal scenario, for 6 to 12 months, after which we would revert the MFN back to something similar to the EU’s Common External Tariff.
Our approach to the MFN will depend to a degree on our negotiations with the EU on a comprehensive trade deal that removes all tariff barriers.
If we get a good trade agreement, then the MFNs can effectively be whatever we like; if we get No Deal, then we are potentially back in No Deal territory and the Unilateral Liberalisation may again apply for a period.
The problem with Unilateral Liberalisation is that it gives overseas trading nations largely tariff-free access to our markets without them needing to give anything in return: a number of Trade deals have foundered as a result – why would a third country sign up to a Trade Agreement when they already have everything they need?
In February 2020, a public consultation launched on gov.uk. On of its purposes was to request of traders and UK business in general for feedback on the CET – to understand the drivers that may cause the UK to deviate from the EU’s duties.
We got 1,300 responses and these will be revealed in last week of March.
The Tariff team will need to stay close to the MFN policy leads in Trade Policy Group to understand the proposed direction.
Understanding the commodity code hierarchy & impact on MFNsThis is discussed in vastly more detail in the training guide on commodity codes, however it is useful to discuss with regard to MFN duties as well.
Below is a relatively shallow hierarchy of commodities, leading to an end-line of Natural Chilean sodium nitrate (3102500010).

Apart from the “section”, which is a pseudo-tier in the classification hierarchy, the MFN duty, and indeed any measure at all, cold be attached to any tier (i.e. the four listed beneath the screen grab – it will then inherit down to any child codes.
MFNs are attached at all different levels in the current EU tariff and will again be so in the UK tariff – the new team will need a strategy to work out where best to attach duties to make the minimal imprint of data, while providing complete and correct coverage – how this was done previously is documented in the migration guide.
Erga Omnes

Erga Omnes is a Latin phrase which means “towards all” or “towards everyone”. In trade terms, Erga Omnes is the geographical area group which covers the entire world
All MFN duties (103s and 105s) are created against Erga Omnes, as are the majority of global import measures.
Erga Omnes has a geographical area ID of 1011.
There is an additional country group entitled “All third countries”, with ID 1008, which is used almost identically to Erga Omnes – they are practically interchangeable.
The only difference between the two is that 1011 contains the European Union as a country, whereas this is excluded from 1008.
There are no hard and fast rules about which should be used: Erga Omnes is used more for import measures and All third countries more for export measures, but this is by no means hard and fast.
Please see the migrations guide for information on what to do with Europe, Erga Omnes and All third countries when we are no longer a part of the Union.

Authorised use (End use)
What is authorised use?Goods imported into the EU are regulated by a range of measures aimed at giving EU and UK businesses an equal footing with businesses elsewhere in the world. One of these is End-Use Relief (will be Authorised Use Relief).
This allows a reduced or zero rate of customs duty on some goods when used for specific purposes and within a set time period. End-Use Relief does not apply to VAT or excise duties.
End-Use Relief is available on certain goods imported into the EU that are to be put to a specific use within the customs territory of EU. To be eligible for End-Use Relief, products must meet defined criteria and be identified in the Trade Tariff.
End-use goods include:
* shipwork goods
* aircraft and parts
* hydrocarbon oil
* marine propulsion engines
* military equipment
* fish
* cheese
* casein (used in the cheese industry)
Determining what goods are for ‘authorised use’

Sadly, there is nothing so simple as a flag on a commodity code to define it is intended for authorised use purposes. There are commodity codes which are:


exclusively provisioned to be used for authorised use
under certain circumstances available for authorised use

The simplest way to find a commodity that is designated solely for authorised use is to check for commodities that have measure type 105 (Non preferential duty under end-use) instead of 103 (Third country duty) against them. This is a small faction of the total number of commodities in the hierarchy.
In addition, the descriptions will have pointers to their end-use nature, e.g. containing words such as “for use in" or “for the manufacture of” etc.
As always, there are exceptions: there are some commodities which have both a 103 and a 105 duty against them, as follows – there are just 5:


        
          
Code
Description


8802110010
Helicopters of an unladen weight <= 2.000 kg - For civil use


8802120010
Helicopters of an unladen weight > 2.000 kg - For civil  use


8802200010
Aeroplanes and other powered aircraft of an unladen weight <= 2.000 kg (excl. helicopters and dirigibles) - For civil use


8802300010
Aeroplanes and other powered aircraft of an unladen weight > 2.000 kg but <= 15.000 kg (excl. helicopters and dirigibles) - For civil use


8802400010
Aeroplanes and other powered aircraft of an of an unladen weight > 15.000 kg (excl. helicopters and dirigibles) - For civil use


        
      The importance of authorised use in data migrationWhatever numerical duties are assigned by our MFN team for the post-Implementation period independent trade policy, it is vital that the differentiation between authorised use and standard use is observed.
A trader is required to produce certificate N990 to take advantage of authorised use relief. This certificate should be present as a condition on all 105 duties (this also applies to other end-use measures).
N990 is currently called “EUS - Authorisation for the use of end use procedure (Column 8c, Annex A of Delegated Regulation (EU) 2015/2446)” – a decision was taken to not rename any certificates in the lead-up to the previous EU Exit near-misses. This should be reviewed once more in the lead up to the end of the implementation period, and certificates should be updated to be UK-specific, if time permits.

11.title: Measures
11.content:
MeasuresIntroduction to measuresA measure is the fundamental raison d’être of the tariff – every piece of trade legislation that is intended to impact the trade of goods through a country’s borders must end up in a measure (or usually more than one).
If there is no measure, then the border systems will not react.
A measure is an atomic unit: according to the Tariff, it is “the application, during a certain period, of an aspect of the Union tariff and commercial legislation to goods imported from a certain origin or exported to a certain destination” which sums it up quite nicely.
A measure equates to a single line on the “Trade with the UK tool” - https://www.gov.uk/get-rules-tariffs-trade-with-uk
A measure equates to a single line on the Trade Tariff Service (UKTT) - https://www.trade-tariff.service.gov.uk/sections
Below is a page from the UKTT for Asses (the animal) – each alternating grey & white line is a single measure. Some commodity codes can have hundreds of measures assigned to them.

What a measure is not!The tariff is a sea of intermingled terminologies – terms are used in different senses by different policy areas.
For instance, in Trade Remedies, the term ‘measure’ may be synonymous with ‘case’, e.g. an investigation launched by the TRA against multiple companies/countries. In this case, the ‘case’ will of followed through to its conclusion, result in a number of measures, a Tariff would refer to them – in the case of Trade Remedies, this could result in many thousands of Tariff measures.
A measure is not an overarching policy or specific enactment of that policy: in Tariff terms, that is a regulation.


Measures and Regulations



measure1

Measure



measure2

Measure



measure3

Measure



measure4

Measure



Regulation

Regulation



Regulation--measure1




Regulation--measure2




Regulation--measure3




Regulation--measure4



The UK tariff is currently a combination of EU and national measuresUntil the end of the Transition Period, we remain a part of the EU’s customs union. As a result of this, we do not get to determine our own trade policy: we cannot enforce our own trade agreements (though we can begin to negotiate them); we cannot impose punitive anti-dumping duties, nor can we decide our own MFN duties.
But we can manage certain aspects of the duties & regulatory controls that are applied to imports and exports.
The EU build all of their measures in their Taric application and then export them overnight for common application across all of the 28 member states (including us). This will continue until (at the earliest) Jan 1st 2021.
Meanwhile, the UK (and all of the other members states) as permitted to manage some aspects that influence trade policy, namely:
* VAT
* Excise
* National prohibitions and restrictions

The Tariff is a big relational database centred around the measureThere are training packs dedicated to each of these areas, so this is just a very brief introduction.

Measure types & responsibilities prior to the TP

There are c. 260 measure types in existence prior to the end of the Transition Period (TP).
Some of these have not been used in some time and can be considered as dead, even if they are not formally terminated on the database.
c. 80 of these are VAT and excise measures that DIT will never get involved in
There remain about 85 measure types that will crop up over the course of the next year and will need to be understood, even if some of these are going to be omitted from the UK tariff (in the first instance).
The measure types can be broadly broken in to the following groups, with the table to the right showing the division of responsibility between the EU and the member states, represented for the UK by HMRC.
These will evolve after the TP (Jan 2021).


        
          
Responsibility
Instrument


The EU
Third country (MFN) duties  Tariff preferences in Trade Agreements Quotas in Trade Agreements WTO quotas Autonomous tariff quotas Trade Remedies & safeguards Duty suspensions  Agricultural safeguards Supplementary units  Credibility checks  Surveillance measures  Common prohibitions and restrictions


The member states (HMRC for the UK)
National prohibitions and restrictions VAT Excise


        
      Measure types & responsibilities post-TPAfter the Transition Period, there will be a great degree of similarity in the applicable trade measures. The UK is not revolutionising the types of trade measures that are to be imposed.
The major difference in responsibility will see the MTPO team in DIT’s Trade Policy Group replacing the role of the EU in co-ordinating and maintaining the measures that were previously seen as pan-European.
There are a number of other changes too, as per the notes column
These groups of measure types are detailed in subsequent pages.

        
          
Responsibility
Instrument
Notes


DIT MTPO
Third country (MFN) duties Tariff preferences in Trade Agreements Quotas in Trade Agreements WTO quotas Autonomous tariff quotas Trade Remedies & safeguards Duty suspensions Agricultural safeguards Supplementary units Credibility checks Surveillance measures All prohibitions and restrictions
Yes Yes Yes Yes Yes Yes Yes, but these will become ‘reliefs’ These will be not feature post-IP Yes Managed by CDS risking module No longer required There are only UK P&R


HMRC
National prohibitions and restrictions VAT Excise
Therefore dividing activity makes no sense Yes Yes


        
      National P&RThere are c. 14 national prohibition and restriction type measures that are currently managed by the HMRC tariff management team. In the future, these will be translation into standard measures managed by the MTPO. After the Transition Period, there will be no differentiation between measures formerly provided by the EU and national P&R.

      The CVD measure type is a complete duplicate of measure type 410 (Veterinary control) applied in the Taric measures.
Measures of this type are being removed from the UK Tariff in Feb 2020.
Measures and geographical areasThe data model allows a single measure to be attached to a single geographical area.
In this context a geographical area can mean:
* a single country (or region1)
* a group of countries
The group of countries may be a formal trading bloc, like the EU or CARIFORUM (Caribbean Trading Nations)
In the geography is a group, then individual countries within that group may also be excluded.
For example, while Haiti is a part of CARIFORUM (both officially and in the Tariff), it is excluded from all preferential measures of the Caribbean EPA (Economic Partnership Agreement), as it has yet to ratify the treaty.
[Insert graph here]
Measures and commodity codes

A measure is applied to a single commodity code only
While a trade instrument (FTA, import restriction etc.) may and is likely to cover multiple commodity codes, this results in the creation of many individual measures.
The Tariff database employs inheritance to apply measures – there are up to 13 tiers in the commodity code hierarchy.
In theory, a measure can be applied at any tier in that hierarchy and inherited down. In practice, measures are very rarely assigned at HS chapter (the first tier in the hierarchy).
While this inheritance is great for accelerating the creation of measures, it brings complexity in terms of business rule adherence.
A measure cannot exist in a hierarchy in the same context (i.e. same measure type, same comm code tree, same date period, same measure type etc.) more than once.
So there is no concept of applying a measure at a higher tier in the database and then having it superseded by a more granular exception in a lower tier – you need to be explicit when assigning measures.
Thus, if  commodity X has 10 children, 9 of which require a 0% duty and 1 of which requires a 50% duty, then you must assign the duties explicitly to all 10 commodities
See the commodity code training manual for more information, especially re: business processing rule ME32.
A commodity code or goods nomenclature item is assigned to a measure via two fields, both of which point to the same data item (goods_nomenclature_item_id and goods_nomenclature_sid).
While a commodity code is fully characterised also by its productline_suffix (in places misspelled as producline_suffix), all measures must be assigned to commodity codes with a productline_suffix of 80, therefore this data would be superfluous on the the measure table.

Measures and additional codesA measure can be assigned to a single additional code only.
As with commodity codes, there are multiple fields used to link the measure to the single additional code:
* additional_code_type_id
* additional_code_id
* additional_code_sid
Unlike commodity codes, there is no concept of inheritance with additional codes – the code is given meaning solely by the additional code type (single digit); the additional code ID (three digits) is essentially a meaningless sequentially sourced number.
An additional code is assigned to a measure for multiple reasons, which could potentially be extended in the future:
* to reference a specific company which will be assigned anti-dumping or anti-subsidy duties
* to reference the route of ingress into the Union (wheat & other cereals)
* to reference product usage (e.g. pharmaceutical usage gets a reduced import duty)
* to reference goods pillaged from Syria & Iraq
* to reference the %age content of sugar, flour or milk fats/solids.
See the additional codes training manual for more information on why additional codes are used.
Measures and time periods

Like most (but not all) objects on the tariff database, measures come with validity_start_date and validity_end_date fields.
For measures, validity start dates are mandatory, whereas validity end dates are optional and usually left blank.
Measure start dates usually coincide with the start dates of the regulations that engender them, though that is not always the case: the regulation also usually has no end date.
A measure will have and end date when it is intended to be explicitly end-dated, e.g. a measure related to a quota, where a limited balance is available for a specific period of time, or agri measures which are intended to be updated on a metronomic basis, e.g. unit prices, if we choose to adopt these.
Even though the Taric business processing rules document states that the measure start date under certain circumstances is optional, it is wrong.
The schema requires a measure start date in the format yyyy-mm-dd

Validity start dates and end dates are treated differently in the Tariff.
* Validity start date means 00:00 at the start of the day
* Validity end date means 00:00 at the end of the day.
* Therefore a measure that starts on Jan 1st and also ends on Jan 1st lasts for a full 24 hours and not zero hours.
* There is no concept of time in the tariff for ‘Taric’ measures, i.e. those that fit into the normal EU schema, which we are adopting.
* However, for VAT and excise, the concept of time has been introduced, as this is required to time changes with budget speeches.
Measures and regulationsA measure is associated to two sets of regulations, depending on its status. These are referred to as follows:
Measure-generating regulations
* The measure-generating regulation is mandatory for all measures.
* This is the regulation that gives measures their legal base. The reference to the measure-generating regulation is split into two fields
  - measure_generating_regulation_role
  - measure_generating_regulation_id
Justification regulations
* The term “justification” regulation is short-hand for “justification for closing” – it is used to identify the legal base that causes the regulation to be terminated in the EU. The UK does not have a similar kind of legislative function – we will not be using the justification regulation as a way of formally auditing the closure of regulations. But there are business rules that make this piece of data critical.
* A justification regulation is not created when a measure is started unless an end-date is also supplied – however, if an end date is supplied, then the justification regulation is mandatory. If the end-date is not entered, then the justification regulation must not be supplied.
* The justification regulation must be either:
 - the measure’s measure-generating regulation, or
 - a measure-generating regulation, valid on the day after the measure’s (explicit) end date.
* When we end-date measures in TAP, we always use the measure-generating regulation as the justification regulation.
Measures and footnotes

It is possible to apply footnotes to both commodity codes and to measures.
As with anything else associated to the measure, the footnote is inherited down to child comm codes – therefore if a measure with a footnote is assigned at HS chapter, then both the measure and the footnote are inherited down to all comm codes in that chapter.
A footnote is connected to the measure by a linking table (many-to-many) called footnote_association_measures.
Footnotes are linked to measures for the entirety of the measure’s duration – the association does not have its own start and end dates – which differs from footnotes’ association with commodity codes, which are dated.

[insert graph]
Measures and duties

Duties are applicable to some, but not all measures. If the measure type is set up with data on the “measure_component_applicable_code” field of “0” or “1”, then a component may / must be applied. If the value of this field is “2”, then the component is not permitted.
Examples of where a duty is mandatory are 103 (Third country duty (MFN)) and 142 (Tariff preference)
Examples of where a duty is not permitted are the majority of the prohibition and restriction measures.
Duties may be held in one of two places:


directly assigned to the measure under all circumstances
conditionally assigned to the measure in certain conditions


Directly-assigned duties
* Directly-assigned duties are assigned to measures via the measure_components table
* A duty (direct- or conditionally-assigned) is often made up of more than one component, which are sequenced in ascending order, according to their duty_expression ID
Conditionally-assigned duties
* Conditionally-assigned duties are assigned to measures via the measure_condition_components table, via the measure_conditions table.
* These state that a certain condition needs to be fulfilled for the duty to apply, e.g. a certain entry price or supply of a certificate.
* These relationships are described in full in the measure components training manual.
Measure components and measure condition components[insert graph here]
Measures, conditions and certificates

A measure can be assigned any number of conditions. These are described in full in the measure conditions training manual, but are used to describe to the border systems:


duties that apply under certain circumstances
border control restrictions that apply under certain circumstances), such as the imposition of requiring a certificate or another kind of document.

There is no limit to the number of conditions that can be assigned to a single measure, though the current max (Feb 2020) is 26 conditions.
Please see the detailed “measure conditions” guide for a full overview of conditions in all their different flavours.

[insert graph]
Relationship between measures and quotas

While First Come, First Served (FCFS) quotas are entirely separate objects on the database, it is not possible to allow traders to declare against quotas unless there is a quota measure exposing its presence to the trader – all trade instruments that are to be executed in CHIEF or CDS need measures to make them work.
Similarly, licensed quotas are operated via measures, though they do not have the additional quota data structures associated with them that are used by FCFS quotas.

[insert graph]


The quota structures are linked to the measures via the use of the ordernumber field. This field takes a 6-digit quota order number and is the same data that is managed in the quota_order_number_id field of the quota_order_number table and similar.
For licensed quotas, the data is also entered into this field as a 6-digit code, but always starts ”094”.

Modifying measures

In most cases, making a change to a measure is not actually a case of actually modifying that measure entity, nor the ancillary objects (such as conditions and components).
Most fundamental changes to a measure are achieved by terminating the measure and replacing with an alternative from the date on which the change is scheduled to happen – otherwise, you run the risk of making changes to measures which have already been active and possibly declared against by traders: to change already live data, e.g. the commodity code or the applicable duties is simply not done.
Let’s say the action were to change the measure type of a given measure such that it evolves from being a 551 (provisional anti-dumping duty) to being a 552, a final anti-dumping duty (known as definitive anti-dumping on the EU tariff). Though this is a required use case, it would never be a case of just updating the measure type of the existing measure.
Instead:


the tariff manager would need to provide a date on which to make the change, which should be no earlier than tomorrow
the existing measure is terminated on the date before the supplied change date
a new measure, effectively a clone, is created starting on the change date, with the old measure type replaced with the new.

This applies equally to the measure-generating regulation, the geography to which the measure applies, the applicable duties and conditions.
In addition, changing fundamental details of the measure, such as the quota order number or the reduction indicator are to be achieved via replacing the measure.
If the user is wanting to modify the assigned footnotes, then there is no need to clone the measure: adding a footnote to the existing measure is fine.

The stopped flag

The stopped flag is set to ‘true’ when a regulation ends a measure using a specific function called ‘abrogation’.
This both sets the effective end date in the regulation and the stopped flag in the measures table.
In the UK we are not using this, however be aware that the stopped flag is mandatory.
Please always set the stopped flag to false in all cases.


Explosion level

While this is a field that pertains to the measure type and not the measure itself, it is worth bringing it up here. The explosion level field can formally take 5 values, as per the XSD to the right, however in practice, only the values “8” and “10” are used.
The explosion level indicates how far down the goods classification hierarchy a measure can be assigned and the explosion level corresponds to the significant digits in the comm code. Treating comm codes as being 5 pairs of 2 digits …
11 12 13 10 00 – 8 significant digits (despite the 8th being a zero)
11 12 13 14 00 – 8 significant digits
11 12 13 14 10 – 10 significant digits (despite the 10th being a zero)
11 12 13 14 15 – 10 significant digits
Measures of a measure type that is set to an explosion level of 8 cannot be assigned to the 3rd and 4th of the commodity codes above.
Measures of a measure type that is set to an explosion level of 10 can be assigned to literally any commodity code.
This impacts business rule ME88 (see below).


The reduction indicator
* This field is used to apply preferential Meursing tables to measures.
* The field is not mandatory and in most countries is set to null.
* Alternative values are 1 to 6, which specify the reduction level to be applied to Meursing placeholders. 
* This is discussed in the agricultural duties training manual.

Export refunds

The export refund nomenclature was a specific nomenclature used for the refund on the export of some agricultural products. This nomenclature is composed of a CN code linked to a 4-digit code called “Export refund additional code”.
This has been abandoned since 2013, so the field export_refund_nomenclature_sid should be set to null in all cases.

Entering dutiesDuty sentence deconstructor

The Ruby application had some usability issues in terms of entering duties. See the subsequent guide to components, which deals in the specifics of measure components, but essentially the tariff manager needs to know the measure components and potentially select multiple of these components from dropdowns.
While this offers a decent route to ensure that no business rules are contravened, it is problematic in terms of screen space, especially for complex conditions, where multiple duties are dependent on those conditions.
In addition, it uses a lot of JavaScript, which is not great for accessibility.
Therefore the approach was taken to prototype something simpler – the nattily named duty sentence deconstructor.




This tool is designed to allows you to copy and paste or type any kind of duty string in to a field and have it translated into an actual set of measure components, abided by all the Taric business rules (e.g. only ever using one duty expressions once against a measure).
The page is unconnected at the moment, but has tested well, both in terms of its usage by policy team members and in terms of translating strings to components.
The tool works via a combination of JavaScript (which is optional) and backend string replacement (in PHP, but easy to replicate in Python).
The tool differentiates between supplementary unit measure types and all others – supplementary units expect to receive only a unit and in extremis a measurement unit qualifier [KGM E (per 1,000), KGM C (net of drained weight) and KGM S (of sugar with a yield in white sugar of 92%) are used] very infrequently.





The MFN measure for white chocolate is on of the more complex duties on the EU tariff. The UK is unlikely to use anything so complex, but must be able to handle similar duties, in case we revert to this level of complexity. The duty is as follows:


9.10 % + 45.10 EUR / 100 kg
MAX 18.90 % + 16.50 EUR / 100 kg

If you copy this into the Duty field, you get a translation of it into the 4 clauses (parts field) and from there into the 4 respective measure components
Most important thing to note is that actually clauses 1, 3 and 4 are effectively the same duty expression – the tool has worked out not to repeat an existing duty expression, hence 01 becomes 04, which becomes 19, so as to not repeat and break business rule ME43.
The validity column to the right is just a check (adding 1, 2, 4 and 8 to make 15) that the expression is valid according to the criteria noted bottom left.
The PHP is rough and ready but should be easily interpretable for translation into Python and componentisation.

Screens – measuresSearch for measures


The search screen is vastly cut down in comparison to the existing TAP measure search screen.
This is a) to save on development time and b) because much of the functionality has not proven to be particularly useful – the original project delivered the capability to search on anything.
Performance is a challenge on search results, as the data needs to be returned from multiple tables, especially re: duties and conditions, and especially where the SQL contains a LIKE clause.
Search should be against at least all of the criteria on the screen to the left.
In the case of commodity code and regulation, the operator dropdown should include both “is one of” and “starts with” to allow exact matches, stemmed matches and searches against multiple precise items (by request of the policy team).
Use type ahead on measure type, geography and quota order number fields.

Measures search results
Search results screen is common across most data objects – with measures (and quotas), the most important point to note is that there is no left-hand side filter capability - there is no room, as there is so much data that need to be returned. Search results table must include:
* View of number of results returned (above and below table)
* Link to export the entire dataset (not just the current page) to CSV
* Button to work with selected measures (both above and below the table)
* Table in GDS table style, but with font size shrunk to 12 point to fit the requisite volume of data.
* Table headers with sort controls, as appropriate (no value in sorting on measure_sid, duties, exclusions, conditions, footnotes, status).
* Tooltip controls on table headers where appropriate – on this form especially useful on the conditions column, which is complex
* For the measure SID column, it must be possible to select all measures, for use in the “work with” functions
* For each measure, click on the measure_sid column value to navigate to the specific measure
* Click on data in the regulation column to navigate to that regulation.
* Click on data in the type (measure type) column to navigate to that measure type.
* Click on data in the additional code column to navigate to that additional code.
* Click on data in the geography and exclusions column to navigate to that geography.
* Click on data in the QON (Quota order number) column to navigate to that quota order number.
* Show status as icon
* Under table show paging – this screen grab has been doctored to show only 10 results: suggestion is 100 results per page for measures.
Display of complex conditions
The data in the conditions column is potentially very complicated and needs to be represented on the search results form – especially with Trade Remedies, the duties may be held in the conditions and this is perhaps the critical piece of information being sought.
The colour coding is helpful in separating out the components of a condition, all of which are important to the processing of the data in CDS, Gems and Caesar
For each line in the conditions column, this is what is meant:
* blue – the condition code and sequence number
* purple – the reference price (import price greater than …)
* red – the required certificate
* green – the action code
* black – the applicable duties
Not all elements are likely to occur together – in fact the nature of conditions is such that there will either be a reference price or there will be a requirement for a certificate, not both, as per the example to the left. Taking the first row, against commodity 85 41 40 90 41 and additional code B845, the following data applies:


Condition 1 of type A, which requires certificate D018, in which case the declared subheading is allowed
Condition 2 of type A, which states that if no certificate is provided, then the declared subheading is not allowed (i.e. the counterpoint to condition 1)
Condition 1 of type F, which states that if the net free at frontier price (import price) > 0.35 EUR WAT, then apply the duty 0.000%
Condition 2 of type F, which states that if the net free at frontier price (import price) > 0.248 EUR WAT, then apply the difference between import price and duty up to 0.350%
Condition 3 of type F, which states that if the net free at frontier price (import price) > 0.0 EUR WAT, then apply the duty 31.300%

Extreme conditions
View of tooltips for columns that need explaining

Two examples of tooltips where the column data benefits from more explanation – the most important one here is the conditions tooltip, where there is potentially a lot of complex data (as per previous slide).
Yes, this uses colour to indicate meaning, therefore running into some challenge for colour-blind users, however it is not the only indicator of meaning.


Footnotes column – can also get very busy
The image to the left shows the 99 footnotes that currently apply to the import of various dual use goods into the EU.
The import control team should eventually review the complexity of this and reduce, however it is unlikely to happen for day one.

      Key business rules
        
          
#
Rule
Notes


ME1
The combination of measure type + geographical area +   goods nomenclature item id + additional code type + additional code + order   number + reduction indicator + start date must be unique.
Required – extremely high priority     This is actually an understatement of the business rule.   There must be no crossover in dates (start or end date) of measures that shar   the same context (as described by the fields to the left). It is more than   just the start date. This and ME32 can be handled together: develop ME32 and   ME1 falls into place.


ME2
The measure type must exist.
Required – low priority     Measure types will need to be selected from a dropdown   (typeahead), but this should be checked nonetheless


ME3
The validity period of the measure type must span the   validity period of the measure.
Required – low priority     Any date related business rule should be avoided by the   Tariff managers simply not end-dating things – there is no real need to   end-date a measure type, and this should be reasserted.


ME4
The geographical area must exist.
Required – low priority     As per the measure type, this should be avoided by   selecting from a list, however this should be checked.


ME5
The validity period of the geographical area must span the   validity period of the measure.
Required – low priority     As per the measure type check, this is required, but can   be avoided by not end-dating geographical areas (which is unnecessary).


ME6
The goods code must exist.
Required – high priority     Required – this should be checked on first entering the   commodity codes (goods code, commodity code, good nomenclature item id are   all synonymous)


ME7
The goods nomenclature code must be a product code; that   is, it may not be an intermediate line.
Required – high priority     This means that the commodity code must exist with a product   line suffix of “80” and not any other value which would reflect the fact that   the commodity is an intermediate heading and nothing more.


ME8
The validity period of the goods code must span the   validity period of the measure.
Required – high priority     This is one of the more critical rules – commodity   codes do start and end on a regular basis and there must be no commodity   codes that terminate before the end date of the assigned measure(s).     This applies equally to open-ended measures on   commodity codes that are end-dated. If a commodity code is being end-dated,   and there will be a requirement to do so, then any measures against that   commodity code must also be terminated.


ME88
The level of the goods code, if present, cannot exceed the   explosion level of the measure type.
Required – medium priority     This is primarily aimed at export control measures,   which are set at 8-digits rather than at the 10-digits that are reserved for   import measure types. Explosion level is set against the measure type, and   not the measure itself. If the user attempts to assign a measure to a   10-digit commodity when the explosion level is set to 8, then ME88 will be   triggered (see page earlier in deck re: explosion level).


ME16
Integrating a measure with an additional code when an   equivalent or overlapping measures without additional code already exists and   vice-versa, should be forbidden.
Required – high priority     This mostly impacts trade remedies, but also EU   additional code types (most of which will not carry forward), such as route   of ingress additional codes (see separate guide). What this means is that, if   there are measures set up against a combination of a commodity code and an   additional code, then it is not permitted to set up a measure against just   that commodity code (without the additional code).     For instance – a Trade Remedy is in place, where this   has involved creating an anti-dumping measure against a commodity code   (0102030405) and an additional code (C233 – Shanghai Industries). The duty   has been set to 25% (punitive specifically against Shanghai Industries).     It must not be possible to set up a measure for the   same time period, of the same type against just comm code 0102030405 with no   additional code. Border systems do not like ambiguity. Instead, the   additional codes presented for that context must cover the full universe of   options – e.g. residual (All other companies A999, B999, C999) codes are set   up for Trade Remedies.


ME115
The validity period of the referenced additional code must   span the validity period of the measure
Required – medium priority     As with all similar rules, this needs to be checked but   should rarely if ever come up, as Tariff Managers should not be end-dating   additional codes.


ME25
If the measure’s end date is specified (implicitly or   explicitly) then the start date of the measure must be less than or equal to   the end date.
Required – low priority     Should be checked as soon as the dates are entered into   the application. End date will in almost all circumstances by empty (Null)   for measures.


ME32
There may be no overlap in time with other measure   occurrences with a goods code in the same nomenclature hierarchy which   references the same measure type, geo area, order number, additional code and   reduction indicator. This rule is not applicable for Meursing additional   codes.
Required – extremely high priority     This is the mother of all business rules and the one   that is likely to trip DDaT and Tariff Managers up more than any other. This   is an extension of the previously described ME1 to all commodity codes in the   upward hierarchy and all commodity codes in the downward hierarchy.     Therefore it is critical that the development team   works out a way of identifying a commodity’s hierarchy from the available   data. There is no concept of parent / child relationship in the database,   rather a list of sequential numbers and indents which infer the hierarchy.     This business rule is detailed on the next pages and in   the section on import control measures. There are 40+ import control   measures, all of which do broadly one of two things: prohibit goods entirely   from being traded, or require that certain provisions are taken (e.g.   documentation). There are so many measure types precisely to avoid ME32.     See next page for details…


        
      ME32 and Jams, fruit jellies, marmalades


As a tariff manager, I have been asked to create a new measure for ERGA OMNES of type “Import control” at level 4 “with a sugar content exceeding 30% by weight” – 
There is already a measure of type “Import control” at level 8 “Fruit purees obtained by sieving then brought to the boil in a vacuum, the texture and chemical composition of which have not been changed by the heat treatment”
ME32 says no
I can either rejig the measures in the entire hierarchy to suit to new measure OR …
I can invent a new measure type “Import control for sieved fruit puree” … which is what the EU has done, and which we will also need to do in the future.

[have not included from page 60-88]
[have not included create new measures section in this section]

12.title: Certificates
12.content:
CertificatesIntroduction to certificatesWhat are certificates?
The certificates tables in TARIC-based applications store all of the certificates, licences and other conditions that are referenced via measure conditions in order to make the import (or export) of a good conditional on the provision of some entity.
The sole purpose of certificates in this system is to associate them to measures via measure conditions – on their own, they no value and are not exposed to traders via any other means.
This entity is usually a physical or digital document of some description (e.g. a license or official certificate), but it may also be a non-paper condition - the term “certificate” to label the table is definitely more constrictive than the actual subject matter.
A good example of the ‘non-document’ condition is “Y037 - Goods exempted from the prohibition – biathlon equipment’ where the condition references a property of the good being imported, and not an accompanying document.
These oddities are typically linked to measures using the measure_condition_code “Y”. Please read the instruction guide on measure conditions for a detailed insight.

What certificates are not


A certificate is not a representation of the actual document itself
Our database stores only a certificate code (4 digits) and a description of that code
There is no instruction on where to find that document (if the certificate represents an actual document), there is no link to a URL nor guidance on how to complete the certificate
This could be construed as a flaw in the public-facing aspect of the certification model.
There is a feeling of ‘so what’ when confronted with the need for a certificate – the interaction may favour traders that know certification inside out and the regulations that underpin it, but for entryists, the concept can be bewildering
DIT may consider extending the model to allow more information than just a code and basic description to be stored against the certificate, bearing in mind that the majority of such documents or other entities would likely be owned by Defra or on occasion HMRC

Structure of certificates & certificate types



Much like footnotes and additional codes, certificates are made up of a type code and then a specific code, which, when concatenated, form the unique code of the certificate.
For example, the footnote C656 is constructed of a type code © and a specific certificate code (656) – the entire certificate is known as C656.
Certificate type codes are always 1 digit in length and can be any alphanumeric character (upper case). Historically the alphabetical certificate type codes have been used for EU-wide certificates: the numeric certificate type codes are used for national measures.
Certificate codes typically use numeric IDs, running from 001 to 999 can be reused across multiple certificate type codes. While the schema also allows for alphabetical certificate codes, these are rarely used: there are 11 instances of certificate codes using alpha instead of numeric digits.
Certificate codes must be 3 digits in length.

Just because there are a lot of instances of applications of certificates to measure conditions does not mean there is an abundance of certificates
In this period since 2015, 36k+ D (Anti-dumping) type certificates have been used, but this entails the application of just 7 unique certificates.
Who owns certificates?


It is anticipated that there will be numerous owners for certificates across government: Defra, the RPA, ECJU, Trade Remedies Authority for example
In the lead-up to the previous three abortive No Deal EU Exits, the question of migrating certification to a standard that differed from the EU’s was not mentioned – all certification would have remained exactly as-is, for two reasons:


this was the best way to prevent additional ‘accidental’ friction at the border
the expertise and knowledge in government to make informed changes to certification was not there

After the implementation period, the expectation is that standards will diverge to a degree and therefore certification will also diverge, however for Jan 1st 2021, the expectation (that needs to be tested) is that the EU certification will be carried forward as-is.
Please see the document on data migration for more information.

20.title: Additional codes
20.content:
Additional codesIntroduction to additional codesWhat is an additional code?
* As detailed in the training manual on goods nomenclature (commodity codes), in most cases, the 10 digits of the EU commodity code hierarchy are fully sufficient to identify the product that is being traded.
* However, there are certain scenarios where the 10-digits are not enough and an additional 4 digits are required (and sometimes 8) to communicate sufficient information to describe the trade.
* This is where additional codes come in.



Additional codes may be appended to a commodity code to make the number of (effective) digits up to 14, or possibly 18.
Importantly though, there is no such thing as a 14-digit commodity code: commodity codes can be augmented by additional codes, but the two entities are managed completely separately: a single additional code can and usually is appended to multiple commodity codes through the medium of measures; similarly a single commodity code can have an association with multiple additional codes, again through measures applied to a given combination of commodity and additional code.

What are additional codes used for?
* Additional codes are now used to manage:
  * Meursing codes – for sugar, flour and milk duties associated with complex agricultural products
  * Anti-dumping & anti-subsidy duties – to identify the specific company to which a punitive measure is attached
  * Pharma products – to identify that the end use of an imported good is for pharmaceutical purposes, and therefore attracts a reduced duty
  * Differentiating product states / uses / origins (e.g. waste chemicals, underwear [!])
  * Route of ingress – to identify the route goods (wheat & other cereals) take into EU and to apply different tariff or regulatory treatment
  * Works of art – to identify items stolen from Syria and Iraq as a result of wartime activity
* Each of the above uses are discussed in detail on the following slides.
* Additional codes are made up of 4 digits, which are split into two parts:

Structure of additional codes and additional code types
* Much like certificates and footnotes, additional codes are made up of a type and then a specific ID, which, when concatenated, form the unique ID of the additional code. .
* For example, the additional code C233 is constructed of a type © and a specific footnote ID (233) – the entire additional code is known as C233.
* The numeric IDs, running from 001 to 999 can be reused across multiple additional code type IDs.
* While the schema allows for us to use alphanumeric digits for additional codes, not just numeric, these are almost never used and never by the EU – there are 7 national additional codes that are used by HMRC for VAT and excise.
* The use of the alphanumeric codes may be of great importance to the Northern Ireland protocol, subject to the way in which the solution progresses.
* Additional code type IDs are always single alphabetical characters (those set by the EU) or single numeric characters (set as national additional code by the UK).
