Type 2 - Preference codesThere are only two remaining reasons in the EU tariff for using preference type additional codes – when the UK takes over ownership, there will be just one.

        
          
Code(s)
Description & notes


2   500     2   501
These   two codes are used to differentiate between the duties applicable to imported   goods which may or may not be subject to reduced duties for pharmaceutical   products. In the EU, this is legislated for in Annex I of the “Combined   Nomenclature”, Part Three, Section II (pharmaceutical products).          In   the UK these additional codes will persist, though the specific legislative   mechanism for persisting them remains to be decided.


2   550     2   551     2   552     2   553
These   codes are used in the EU to apply differential duties to goods (wheat,   sorghum and other cereal goods) dependent upon their route of ingress into   the European Union.          These   will not be persisted into the UK tariff: a) because we are not carrying   forward the operationalising of the agricultural policy to apply variable   duties on cereals (though we are retaining the right to revert if required)   and b) the routes are not relevant to a newly-independent UK.


        
      Type 3 – P & R codesThese codes are on the surface vey similar to those used under additional code type 4 – it is not clear why one might be used in opposition to the other.

        
          
Code(s)
Description & notes


3   200     3   202     3   203     3   204     3   205     3   206     3   207     3   208     3   249
These   additional codes are used to differentiate between specific states of certain   chemical compounds: if the product is in a certain state, then a different   export code restriction applies, as explained in the footnote:          “The   surveillance does not apply to mixtures and natural products which contain   scheduled substances and which are compounded in such a way that the   scheduled substances cannot be easily used or extracted by readily applicable   or economically viable means, to medicinal products as defined in point 2 of   Article 1 of Directive 2001/83/EC of the European Parliament and of the   Council and to veterinary medicinal products as defined in point 2 of Article   1 of Directive 2001/82/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council.”          The   purpose of the these codes is to provide the ability to slice multiple   commodities according to their intrinsic properties.


3   601     3   602     3   603
I   kid you not – this group of additional codes is to apply additional   restrictions to the import of pants and bras from North Korea. The additional   code provides an additional slide over the top of the existing commodities   without creating multiple new comm codes.


        
      Type 4 – Restriction codesThink of this type of additional codes as a means of differentiating between:
potential multiple uses of goods, where splitting all the codes would be inadvisable, complex, confusing, or impossible
a way of differentiating origin / specifics, even if via several intermediary steps

        
          
Code(s)
Description & notes


4   008 – 4 099
These   codes have been instituted as a means of instituting temporary controls   (restrictions) on goods that have been plundered following the chaos in Iraq   and Syria, for example after the destruction of Palmyra. Rather than   permanently splitting existing commodity codes, typically (but not   exclusively) in chapters 97 and 98 (works of art) etc., the European   Commission has created additional codes to determine origin of goods, even if   they have passed through multiple trades prior to the entry into the EU. For   this reason, many of the controls apply not just to Iraq and Syria, but also   to Erga Omnes / All third countries (1011, 1008 respectively).          Chapters   97 and 98 are very shallow – in some cases, the definitions only go down to   HS4 without any further cleaving of codes – the EU cannot introduce codes at   6 digits, even if that was desirable, so the choice would have been: create a   very few additional codes to designate source OR create a large number of   10-digit codes to represent permanent splits.


4   115 to 4 118
Used   to apply controls to waste materials and ozone-depleting substances


4   200 to 4 212
Used   to differentiate the skins and furs of wild cats (e.g. lynxes) as well as   other mammals sometimes (illegally) used for their fur (e.g. otters &   pine martens)


        
      Type 7 - Meursing codes

Introduced in 1988 by the European Commission. Traders hate them, but we have to keep Meursing classifications or change our WTO commitments.
They apply to bakery and confectionery products, etc. classed as “composite agrigoods”. Meursing allows extra set of import duties to be charged depending on how much of 4 agricultural ingredients are used to make the product: milk fat, milk proteins, starch or glucose, or various forms of sugar.
The result used to be tens of thousands of categories of composite agrigoods for the purposes of charging import duties. To find the specific ‘recipe’ and the duties applicable, you look it up in the Meursing table (right).
Executed in the tariff as a combination of primary measures, such as tariff preferences, with complex duty expression combinations, which are then expanded when the trader select the ‘additional code’ for the specific ‘recipe’ of their product.
The best description of Meursing codes and their use is drawn up by Trade expert Peter Unghpakorn on his trade beta blog: https://tradebetablog.wordpress.com/2016/08/18/eu-tariff-biscuit-annex1/



Future of Meursing codes


The Meursing code is a staple of EU agrifood trade.
The UK policy however is to abandon Meursing codes as an agricultural policy, due to the fact that it is universally disliked by trade and policy (Defra) alike – the tax-raising reasons for it having come into existence in the first place are not UK policy.
However, as with much of the Northern Ireland protocol, there are additional implications for UK government and Northern Ireland traders with NI remaining in a special relationship with the EU’s Customs Union.
Initial thoughts are that the impact of the NI protocol will not be felt for GB traders, but NI traders will continue to need to apply Meursing codes to imports of specific types if the good is considered to be at risk of being further transported to the EU.
At the very least, this requires DIT policy and DDaT to retain some knowledge of the Meursing challenge, even if the majority of the UK will not be subject to the controls

Application of a Meursing code in detail – Waffles and wafers
* Let’s take “waffles and wafers - with a water content exceeding 10% by weight”, commodity code 1905320500.

* The third country duty reads as follows:9.00% + EA MAX 20.7% + ADFM
* This is a complex compound duty involving both a ceiling and a pair of Meursing-related placeholders. These placeholders come in three forms, which, in the EU are labelled:
* EA – Agricultural component 
* ADFM – Additional duty on flour
* ADSZ – Additional duty on sugar (not shown here, but the principle applies)
* The labels are based on French and German abbreviations (élément agricole, farine / mehl; sucre / Zucker)
* The next section shows the breakdown – and what traders have to do

Unpicking complex agricultural duties
* The waffle duty 9.00% + EA MAX 20.7% + ADFM is made up of 4 measure components – please review the training manual on measure components for a detailed view of these.

        
          
Duty expression ID
Duty amount
Commentary


01
9.00
Ad valorem duty


12
-
Meursing placeholder –   agricultural component


17
20.7
Ceiling ad valorem ( … up to a   maximum of …)


27
-
Meursing placeholder – additional   duty on flour


        
      

The first thing to notice is that the Meursing placeholders have no duties assigned to them – it is not possible to assign duty amounts to these measure components; they operate as placeholders that are filled in only when traders declare the content of the various delicious ingredients.
The trader goes to (for example) the gov.uk URL below, enters the component %ages and then is eventually presented with a 4-digit code, such as 7364.
Duties are then assigned specifically against the Meursing additional code 7364, totally independent of the hundreds of commodities that are subject to them – this is unique in the tariff database, where duties are usually against combinations of commodity codes and additional codes - not with Meursings.


https://www.gov.uk/additional-commodity-code
Implications for Tariffs project


Although it is theoretically possible that the UK will need to manage Meursing additional codes and their associated duties in the future, it is highly unlikely
Recommendation would be that no interface functionality is constructed to allow for managing Meursing codes themselves, as it is hugely complex.
Theoretically, if we wanted to just change the duties associated with the Meursing additional codes, this is possible: it is a matter of assigning duties direct to an additional code, rather than to a combination of commodity codes and additional codes.

Meursing table and the reduction indicator


There is one Meursing table but multiple layers of tariffs assigned against it
The “reduction indicator” is assigned to the tariff measure on the commodity code and to the duty assigned to the additional code. The border system picks the indicator that matches to select the right duty.
In use with multiple preferential agreements that reference composite agrigoods.
Japan goes to town on the usage of reduction indicators, forcing the EU to change its Taric schema to accommodate another three reduction tables.
By the end of the implementation period, be aware of two facts:
we will have done away with the concept of Meursing codes in the UK, therefore the reduction indicator will be irrelevant
we will not have a trade agreement with Japan
BUT:
we will need to honour the NI protocol, meaning Meursings will apply to imports of at risk goods from RoW and GB to NI, meaning DIT and DDaT need to continue to be aware of their presence.


Type 8, A, B, C – Anti-subsidy / anti-dumping codesA Trade Remedy is explained elsewhere, but the important thing to note is that, for the two types of trade remedy that are by some distance the most abundant, Anti-dumping duties and Anti-subsidy duties, the punitive import duties are set against specific exporting companies that are deemed to have acted unlawfully, not against entire countries.
Essentially, a company is proven to have been dumping1 its goods on an overseas market (e.g. the European Union or the United Kingdom), or to have been receiving unlawful state subsidy to undercut international competitors, and this activity is found to have been damaging businesses in those overseas nations. In such cases, the nation or bloc’s Trade Remedies body, such as our own Trade Remedies Authority, is entitled to investigate and impose punitive duties specifically against the companies that have been proven to have acted unlawfully.
In the case of Trade Remedies, the 4-digit additional code is set to represent the company from which the good is imported, or in some cases, a multitude of companies that have been found guilty of the same infraction.


By way of example:
Code C316 refers to Bengang Steel Plates Co., Ltd (Benxi, Liaoning)
Code C333 refers to all of:
* Aeolus Tyre Co., Ltd;
* Aeolus Tyre (Taiyuan) Co., Ltd;
* Qingdao Yellow Sea Rubber Co., Ltd;
* Pirelli Tyre Co., Ltd
To create a punitive trade remedy duty against a the import of “flat rolled steel” from “Bengang Steel Plates”, you assign a 552 measure against commodity code 7225990092 and additional code C316.

When the European Commission first set up the Taric database to cater for all trade eventualities, they were somewhat guilty of short-sightedness when it came to Trade Remedies.
They set up the additional type code ‘8’ in 1972 to deal with all future companies implicated in Trade Remedy cases. To be fair, this lasted until 1999, when the 1,000 possible permutations within the ‘8 ‘ type code (000 to 999) were exhausted. They then moved on to using ‘A’. In 2013, they moved on to ‘B’ and in ‘2015’ to ‘C’. By 2019, type ‘C’ was already half used up, so the expectation would be that they will move on to another additional code type within the next 2 years.
‘D’ is already used for dual use codes, albeit it is currently dormant.
In preparing for the multiple abortive stabs at EU Exit, the project team has (via scripts) created an additional set of additional code types (‘E’ and ‘F’) to cater for the inevitable expansion and deviation.
Additional codes, according to the Taric schema may be alphabetical, as well as numeric – alpha characters have never been used by the EU, but there is no reason why we could not use them in the future in the UK.


Additional codes used in Trade Remedies measures are essentially meaningless beyond Tariff – there is literally no reference against any international database of companies, nor any attempt to make the data set atomic and ‘cleansed’
You are likely to find multiple instances of the same company cropping up in the database on multiple occasions.
Be careful about the shenanigans that companies get up to evade punitive duties – most often by setting up subsidiaries in overseas nations with similar names: these are not the same company, nor the same additional code, but they may have very similar company names.

Additional codes cannot be applied universally …
There is an additional many to many table within the tariff database that determines which additional code types can be used against which measure types. Currently there are 74 permutations of additional codes against measure types: there is little surprising about the alignment – e.g. you can only assign additional codes of type 8, A, B or C to measure types that are associated with Trade Remedies.

Additional codes, additional code types data entities

Screen designs[LEAVING THIS SECTION OUT AS NOT YET DECIDED WHERE THIS SECTION SHOULD BE PLACED IN THE MANUAL - REFER TO PAGES 28 - 45 ON POWERPOINT SLIDES]
Key user needs – additional codes
        
          
As a …
I want to …
So that …
Notes


UK Tariff Manager
view a list of existing additional code   types
I can select and decide the next   appropriate actions to be performed.
Must Have


UK Tariff Manager
create a new additional code type
I can present it on the system and to   be assigned to selected additional codes.
Must Have


UK Tariff Manager
edit the description / start date of an   existing additional code type
I can update the changes imposed and   also be sent to the relevant external systems.
Must Have


UK Tariff Manager
terminate an existing additional code   type
I won’t accidentally select a retired   additional code type(s) on the system.
Could Have


UK Tariff Manager
view a list of all additional code(s)
I can have a consolidated view of all   existing additional codes.
Must Have


UK Tariff Manager
view a list of additional code   associated with a given additional code    type
I can have a consolidated view of all   assigned additional codes.
Should Have


UK Tariff Manager
create a new additional code
I can present it on the system and to   be assigned to selected measures.
Must Have


UK Tariff Manager
edit the description of an existing   additional code
I can update the changes imposed and   also be sent to the relevant external systems.
Must Have


UK Tariff Manager
terminate an existing additional code
I won’t accidentally select a retired   additional code(s) on the system.
Could Have


UK Tariff Manager
have a workflow process
All certificate changes can be   validated and approved before being sent to CDS.
Must Have


UK Tariff Manager
have the system validate relevant   business rules accordingly
It won’t cause errors when validated in   CDS.
Should Have


UK Tariff Manager
have a search filter
I can find the additional codes I need   quickly.
Must Have


        
      Key business rules – additional codes
        
          
#


Rule


Notes


Core   additional code type rules








CT1
The additional code type must be unique.



Required     We are providing the opportunity to create new additional   code types, as these will be required to extend with regard to Trade Remedies   when additional code type ‘C’ runs out.



CT2
The Meursing table plan can only be entered if the   additional code type has as application code “Meursing table additional   code type”.



Not required     This field should not be exposed in the interface – value   should always be Null



CT3
The Meursing table plan must exist.



Not required     This field should not be exposed in the interface – value   should always be Null



CT4
The start date must be less than or equal to the end date.



Required     Simple data comparison (if required) – however the   creation pages for all objects such as additional codes will not feature an   end date function – the edit screens will though.



Delete   an additional code type     We can   sidestep all of these by not allowing for the deletion of additional code   types – highly recommended.








CT6
The additional code type cannot be deleted if it is   related with a non-Meursing additional code.



Not Required     We should not permit deletion of additional code types



CT7
The additional code type cannot be deleted if it is   related with a Meursing Table plan.



Not Required     We should not permit deletion of additional code types –   The Meursing plan is 99% certain to become a thing of the past in any case.



CT9
The additional code type cannot be deleted if it is   related with an Export refund code.



Not Required     We should not permit deletion of additional code types –   ERNs are also dead objects



CT10
The additional code type cannot be deleted if it is   related with a measure type.



Not Required     We should not permit deletion of additional code types



CT11
The additional code type cannot be deleted if it is   related with an Export Refund for Processed Agricultural Goods additional   code.



Not Required     We should not permit deletion of additional code types –   ERNs are also dead objects



#
Rule



Notes



ACN1
The combination of additional code type + additional code   + start date must be unique.



Required     Additional codes are uniquely identified by their   additional code type and additional code fields, which in conjunction, at any   given time are unique. However code combinations can be reused over time,   hence the use of the additional code SID field – an internal identifier to   identify specific instances of these combinations, as they may be reused.   Therefore this must be checked.     In actual fact, the rule is written incorrectly here.   There must be no overlap in time between two codes both identified with the   same additional code type and additional code – you need to check for this   overlap, which is not permitted, rather than just the coincidence of the   validity start date.



ACN2
The referenced additional code type must exist and have as   application code “non- Meursing” or “Export Refund for   Processed Agricultural Goods”.



Required     See earlier in this document for more info on   additional code type application codes. The most crucial piece is to ensure   that the additional code type actually exists.



ACN3
The start date of the additional code must be less than or   equal to the end date.



Required     Simple date comparison, which will be impacted when an   additional code is being edited – there is no option to enter an end date on   creation.



ACN4
The validity period of the additional code must not   overlap any other additional code with the same additional code type +   additional code + start date.



Required (but see ACN1)     This is a cack-handed way of explaining ACN1 – the two   can be delivered in conjunction by using the business rule explained against   ACN1 above



ACN12
When the additional code is used to represent an   additional code line table component then the validity period of the   additional code must span the validity period of the component.



Not required     Used for complex Meursing code applications – we are   expecting to not use Meursing codes / table.



ACN13
When an additional code is used in an additional code   nomenclature measure then the validity period of the additional code must   span the validity period of the measure.



Required     This will be most frequently used in Trade Remedies   (anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures). As always, this is best countered   by not putting an end date on an additional code, but should be checked   anyway.



ACN17
The validity period of the additional code type must span   the validity period of the additional code.



Required     As above, we should simply never end-date additional   codes, but strictly–speaking, this is required.



#
Rule



Notes



Footnote   association








ACN6

The footnotes that are referenced must exist.

Not required     There is no means of publicly viewing footnotes associated   with additional codes, therefore the feature is redundant




ACN7

The start date of the footnote association must be less   than or equal to the end date of the footnote association.

Not required     There is no means of publicly viewing footnotes associated   with additional codes, therefore the feature is redundant




ACN8

The period of the association with a footnote must be   within (inclusive) the validity period of the additional code.

Not required     There is no means of publicly viewing footnotes associated   with additional codes, therefore the feature is redundant




ACN9

The period of the association with a footnote must be   within (inclusive) the validity period of the footnote.

Not required     There is no means of publicly viewing footnotes associated   with additional codes, therefore the feature is redundant




ACN10

When the same footnote is associated more than once with   the same additional code then there may be no overlap in their association   periods.

Not required     There is no means of publicly viewing footnotes associated   with additional codes, therefore the feature is redundant




ACN11

The referenced footnote must have a footnote type with   application type = "non-Meursing additional code footnotes”.

Not required     There is no means of publicly viewing footnotes associated   with additional codes, therefore the feature is redundant




Additional   code description and description periods








ACN5

At least one description is mandatory. The start date of   the first description period must be equal to the start date of the   additional code. No two associated description periods may have the same   start date. The start date must be less than or equal to the end date of the   additional code.

Required    On creating the additional code in the first instance, the first   description must commence on the same start date as the additional code. On   editing the description, this will need to be checked. We must not allow   users to delete the first applicable description.




Delete   an additional code








ACN14

An additional code cannot be deleted if it is used in an   additional code nomenclature measure.

Required     The new project should consider not allowing additional   codes to be deleted – there will scarcely be a requirement to do so.




ACN15

An additional code cannot be deleted if it is used in an   additional code line table component.

Not Required     This refers specifically to Meursing code additional codes   – we will not be providing the capability to manage this relationship, but   most importantly, as above: we should consider not allowing additional codes   to be deleted.

22.title: Geographical areas
22.content:
Geographical areasIntroduction to geographical areas

All measures must be assigned to a single geographical area entity.
This entity, derived from the geographical_areas view may itself be:


a single country (like Namibia)
a group of countries (like Cariforum [a Caribbean trading bloc])
a region – which is a slight misnomer, meaning as it does a country that has yet to be 
fully incorporated, like Kosovo, which remains partially recognised.

A quota though may be assigned to multiple geographical area entities. While this is the case in the EU, the UK is trying to abandon this, for example there is a wine quota (09.1530) in use for the West Balkan countries1 that is going to be split into 6 individual quotas post-implementation period.
A geographical area that is defined as being a country group will have one or more countries (or regions) designated as members of that country group.

Identifying geographical areas

An identifier for a country group (geographical_area_id) is structured depending on the type of area in question.
The geographical code field dictates what type of geographical area is involved:


0 Country
1 Country group
2 Region

For all countries and regions, the code is a 2-digit upper-case alphabetical string


For countries, this is based on the international standard (ISO_3166-1) (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_3166-1_alpha-2)
For regions, i.e. unincorporated states, the code is typically a 2-digit string beginning with X, followed by the first letter of the country. e.g. as an upshot of the splintering of the former Yugoslavia, Serbia and Kosovo were formed as ‘regions’, not countries: Serbia = XS, Kosovo = XK. Even though Serbia is now a fully recognised sovereign state, it remains a region (practical implications of flipping; Kosovo is still officially considered to be a part of Serbia by over half the world).

For country groups, the code is an alpha-numeric string of 4-digits.


For country groups set up by the EU, these 4-digit strings are always numeric, e.g. 1001 = Erga Omnes (whole world)
For nationally setup groups (historically managed by HMRC), the groups are alpha-numeric, for example F006 (Phytosanitary certificates)


About country groupsThe last example on the previous page (F006 Phytosanitary certificates) shows that the country groups do not have to align to an enshrined globally understood trading entity like EU (1011), CARIFORUM (1033) or GSP LDC (2005).
Because the meat and drink of Taric and TAP is to produce measures, which can be connected to just one single geographical area, it is often simpler just to create a group of countries and apply the measure to the group and not the individual countries.
This can often be at the expense of making total sense however. For example, to execute the regulations associated with handloomed products, a group has been set up to accommodate the countries to which a quota applies for such products – the name of the group is “Silk or cotton handloom products”.

Geographical area membershipGeographical areas that represent country groups (area code 1) are designed to include member countries
A geographical area group can only contain regions or countries (area codes 0 and 2), not other geographical area groups – any attempt to assign a country group to another country group as a member must not be permitted and cause a business rule failure at HMRC. A geographical area’s membership of a country group is bookended by a start date and potentially and end date, where absolutely required.
While geographical areas are absolutely not a volatile area within the application, and the changes are few and far between, there are a number of use cases where membership does change, albeit infrequently. For example, countries move in and out of GSP tiers from year to year as their progress or decline economically.
Steel safeguards work on country groups created specifically for the purpose of applying punitive duties against large numbers of countries; these groups tend to change from year to year, as we learn more about the impact of the punitive duties on trade flows.
The UK may choose to create country groups to apply specific regulatory controls.
Relationship of measures to geographical areas

All measures are assigned to precisely one geographical area.
That area may be a country, region (non-incorporated country) or a group of countries.
If the geographical area is a country group, then it is possible to exclude (one or more) members of that country group from the measure via inclusion in the measure_excluded_geographical_areas table.
The excluded country must be a member of that group.
Please note: both the excluded_geographical_area and geographical_area_id fields refer to the excluded country, not the group.

Relationship of quotas to geographical areas

All quotas need to be represented both as measures and within the structures related to quotas.
With licensed quotas, these are only represented by quotas.
The relationship of geographical areas to quotas needs to be reflected in both the measures and quotas structures (except for licensed quotas).
Therefore both the relationship of quotas to their origins and measures to the related geographical areas needs to be managed and synchronised in the data creation.

Key user needs – geographical area
        
          
As a …
I want to …
So that …
Notes


Tariff Manager
create a new geographical area of type country or region
I can assign duties or regulatory measures specifically to that country or region
MUST HAVE This will be an extremely infrequent activity; very few new countries spring up. Fields required: -Start date -Geographical area ID -Description -Area code (0 or 2)


Tariff Manager
create a new geographical area of type ‘country group’
I can implement measures or quotas against more than one country via the same action
MUST HAVE Expected to be required up to 10 times a year (max) Fields required: -Start date -Geographical area ID -Description -Area code (1)


Tariff Manager
update the description of a country group or country or region
the description best reflects the current status of that country
MUST HAVE Countries change name vey irregularly; in the outset, there are c. 40 changes required for countries whose descriptions are not ISO-compliant. After that, countries change name no more than c. one instance per year Fields required: -Start date -Description


Tariff Manager
add a member country or region to a country group from a given start date
the country group can best reflect the policy requirement
MUST HAVE


Tariff Manager
terminate a country or region’s membership of a country group
I won’t accidentally assign a retired/incorrect membership.
SHOULD HAVE This id a rare scenario to happen. Can also use end-dates to achieve the same outcome.


Tariff Manager
assign measure(s) to a geographical area of any of the given types
Only the correct county/region will be affected.
SHOULD HAVE This can be done through the measure creation initially.


Tariff Manager
exclude one or more countries from a measure, where that measure is assigned to a group of countries
Only the correct county will be affected.
MUST HAVE


Tariff Manager
assign quota order number(s) to a geographical area of any of the given types
Only the correct quota order number(s) will be affected.
SHOULD HAVE This can be done through the quota creation initially.


Tariff Manager
exclude one or more countries from a quota (order number), where that measure is assigned to a group of countries
Only the correct county will be affected.
SHOULD HAVE This can be done through the quota creation initially.


Tariff Manager
have a workflow process
All certificate changes can be validated and approved before being sent to CDS.
Must Have


Tariff Manager
have the system validate relevant business rules accordingly
It won’t cause errors when validated in CDS.
Should Have


Tariff Manager
have a search filter
I can find the geographical areas I need quickly.
Must Have


        
      Key business processing rules – geographical areas
        
          
#
Rule
Notes
MoSCoW


GA1
The combination geographical area id + validity start date must be unique.
Required
Must Have - While it is theoretically possible for there to be two areas with the same ID, and different start dates it has never happened. This rule should nonetheless be checked on the creation and update of a country group


GA2
The start date must be less than or equal to the end date.
Required
Must Have


GA3
At least one description record is mandatory. The start date of the first description period must be equal to the start date of the geographical area. Two descriptions may not have the same start date. The start date of the description must be less than or equal to the end date of the geographical area.
Required
Must Have - As a ‘type 2’ data object where the description can change over time (e.g. Western Samoa), the geographical_area object cannot exist without at least 1 description record & equivalent period record that starts on the same day as the geographical area record.


GA4
The referenced parent geographical area group must be an existing geographical area with area code = 1 (geographical area group).
Not required
Won’t Have - The simplest and best way to deal with any business rules regarding parent geographical areas is to not set them up: TAP should set this field to null for all new geographical areas – the field is redundant, but still has business rules associated with it – to manage memberships, use the geographical_area_memberships many to many table.


GA5
If a geographical area has a parent geographical area group then the validity period of the parent geographical area group must span the validity period of the geographical area.
Not required
Won’t Have - As above


Relationship with measures





GA6
Loops in the parent relation between geographical areas and parent geographical area groups are not allowed. If a geographical area A is a parent geographical area group of B then B cannot be a parent geographical area group of A (loops can also exist on more than two levels, e.g. level 3; If A is a parent of B and B is a parent of C then C cannot be a parent of A).
Not required
Won’t Have - As above


GA7
The validity period of geographical area must not overlap any other geographical area with the same geographical area id.
Required This should be handled at the same time as GA1 (above)
Won’t Have


GA10
When a geographical area is referenced in a measure then the validity period of the geographical area must span the validity period of the measure.
Required
Must Have - Unless explicitly required, a geographical area should be left open-ended to avoid this error – there is rarely a need to terminate a country group, especially as there is no public-facing aspect to this: however, in certain cases, e.g. a regularly refreshed pseudo-group (like used for steel safeguards) or countries whose borders have shifted as a result of wars (Serbia and Montenegro), this is still required. It is vital however that end dates are applied sparingly.


GA11
If a geographical area is referenced as an excluded geographical area in a measure then the membership period of the (excluded) geographical area must span the validity period of the measure.
Required
Must Have - As above – this is typically avoided by NOT end-dating geographical areas


Relation with geographical area membership





GA12
The referenced geographical area id (member) must exist.
Required
Must Have


GA13
The referenced geographical area id (member) can only be linked to a country or region (area code = 0 or 2).
Required
Must Have


GA14
The referenced geographical area group id must exist.
Required
Must Have


GA15
The membership start date must be less than or equal to the membership end date.
Required
Must Have


GA16
The validity period of the geographical area group must span all membership periods of its members.
Required
Must Have


GA17
The membership period of a geographical area (member) must be within (inclusive) the validity period of the geographical area group (geographical area’s start and end date).
Required
Must Have


GA18
When a geographical area is more than once member of the same group then there may be no overlap in their membership periods.
Required
Must Have


GA19
If the associated geographical area group has a parent geographical area group then all the members of the geographical area group must also be members of the parent geographical area group.
Required
Must Have - But avoid creating parent groups, or terminating existing parent groups


GA20
If the associated geographical area group has a parent geographical area group then the membership period of each member of the parent group must span the membership period of the same geographical area in the geographical area group.
Required
Must Have But avoid creating parent groups, or terminating existing parent groups


Delete a geographical area





GA21
If a geographical area is referenced in a measure then it may not be deleted1.
Required
Must Have - Though we should never be deleting geographical areas.


GA22
A geographical area cannot be deleted if it is referenced as a parent geographical area group.
Required
Must Have


Delete a geographical area membership





GA23
If a geographical area is referenced as an excluded geographical area in a measure, the membership association with the measure geographical area group cannot be deleted.
Required
Must Have
